(CP. 1381).Board of Trade,Great George Street,SJM.My dear Hankey^17th June, 1920..With reference to your letter of the 4th June, I enclose a note containing observations Tjpon those portions of the French memorandum concerning which the Board of Trade are in a position to speak, that is to say those dealing with the coal and dye-stuffs Annexes to the Reparation Clauses, the Economic Clauses and the Ports, Waterways and Railways Clauses of the Treaty of Peace. Under the Reparation questions the observations of Sir John Bradbury, who is better in a position to say how far the Germans have omitted to carry out their obligations, will no doubt be obtained. It does not appear to be alleged that there has been any serious failure by the German Government in the execution of the Ports, Waterways and Railways Clauses. The only point of importance under the Economic Section in which a complaint can reasonably be made that that Government is failing to meet its undertakings is in relation to the German import and export policy, and on this matter a note to the German Government has been pre-pared by an inter-allied Committee, and approved by the Conference of Ambassadors subject on the part of the United States represent-ative to formal confirmation by his Government. It is understood ^that the French hope to get this matter settled amicably with the Germans before the Spa Conference.Certain points relating to the Industrial Property Clauses upon which the Germans appear to have adopted a wrong, inter-pretation were referred by the Conference of Ambassadors some weeks ago to a Meeting of Allied technical experts which was to be summoned by ihe French Government. Thia Meeting has not yei been called. - - ..."Yours sincerely, (sgd.) R.S. Home.Lieutenant-Colonel Sir Maurice Hankey.,'G.C.B REPARATIONS CLAUSES.Annex V.Coal.- (Page 24). The Board of Trade have no observations upon this part of the memorandum which is simply a statement of facts.Annex VI,_(Page 26\* -.;Dyestuffa *Under this Annex the Germans have. the. obligation to deliver a proportion of their stocks of dyestuffs and also a share in the current output. Allocation of Reparation dyes from stock has been made, some quantities have been received and the rest Of the British quota is either on Its way to this country or shipment of it has been arranged for* As regards the current output, there was some delay on the part of the Germans in furnishing information, but satisfactory arrangements have now been made in regard to the supply of the dyestuffs to which the Allies are entitled..Chemical DrugsThis country has not exercised its option upon the stocks or output of drugs in Germany.Part X. Economic Glauses. (Page 27).W The Levying of import duties in gold. (Page 28), The British Government have from the first been unable to accept the French contention that this was a contravention of Article 269 of the Treaty of Peace, and as is stated in the memorandum the principle of levying import duties at the pre-war rate in gold was admitted by the Supreme Council and the Reparation Commission,,(2) The Regulation of imports and exports o^ (Pagcs,28J30)* Evidence brought forward by the Belgian,; French and Italian Governments that the German Government had differentia-ted against Allied countries in regard to imports and exports in in contravention of Articles 264-266 was considered by an inter-allied committee upon which this country was represented, and the effect-of the report of the Committee, which has been accepted by His Majesty's Government, is fairly. and accurately given in the memorandum,, A note to the German Government based on this report has just been drafted by the Committee and approved by the Conference of Ambassadors, subject, on the part of the United States representative, to the approval of his Government. . Copy of this note is annexed. (5) Unfair Competition._(Page 31).*Under Articles 274 and 275, Germany undertakes to adopt all measures necessary to protect goods of Allied origin from unfair competition. We have no information of any measures as yet taken by Germany in application of these articles.(4) Taxation of Foreigners. (Page 51).The Board of Trade are not aware of any protest by His Majesty's Government under Article 276 against differential prices charged in Germany to Foreigners, and have not received evidence of any secret orders- from the German Administrative Authorities to shop-keepers and Hotel proprietors that higher prices should be charged to Foreigners than to Germans. In any case they feel doubtful whether charges of this kind are intend-ed to be covered by Article 276 (c).'5) Industrial Property. (Pages 51-34).Under Article 307 each of the High Contracting Parties undertakes to accord a period of at least one year from the coming into force of the Treaty for performing any acts or making any payments in connection with obtaining or maintain- -ing Industrial Property acquired before the beginning of the War or which might have been acquired since except for the War.The/ The French Government state that the German Patent Office, wu having since the coming into force of the Treaty granted patents on applications made before or during the War, have demanded immediate payment of removal fees due from the-date of the patent (which is the.date of the application). We are in agreement with the French contention that the period of ono year referred to under Article 307 should apply tn those foes. ..'The second point raised in the French note Is that the German authorities having reJested applications for Patents during the' war on the ground of failure by the applicant to reply to objections raised by the German Patent Office within the period prescribed by the regulations, are insisting upon . upholding.this rejection in spite of the above-mentioned provision that an extension of one yoar from the coming into force of the Treaty shall be accorded for performing obligations which fo&l due during the war. The British Patent Office have suspended decisions as regards patent . rights where the German ov^nor or his agent was not in a position to argue his case during the war, and are in agreement with the French contention on the understanding that it is limited to cases in which there was not a proper and formal hearing at which all interested parties were represented and properly heard.It ie understood that the Conference of ambassadors referred the points raised In the French flote to a Meeting of Allied Technical experts which was to be called by the French authorities, and the British representatives are awaiting a summons to this Meeting.Part It I. Porte, Waterways and Iiailways. (Pages 35-36.)The Board of Trade are in agreement with the statement in the French Biamorandum that, the provisions of this part have not been violated by Germany.
